items.synopsis: A Supreme Court trial has heard that the youngest of eight men accused of the shooting murder of Jason De Ieso at his northern Adelaide workshop was responsible for firing the fatal round.

title.children: Youngest and only 'non-patched' Hells Angels associate alleged to have fired shot that killed Jason De Ieso, court told

image.altText: Antonio Loiacono

items.synopsis: The family and friends of Antonio Loiacono gathered to remember the young footballer who died last month after an on-field collision in the Adelaide Hills.

title.children: Young South Australian athlete's brain donated to further concussion research

image.altText: SA's education minister and health minister stand beside advertising warning students about what's in vapes

title.children: 'Young people have been manipulated': SA government rolls out education campaign to curb vaping

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Previously unpublished internal research from the Reserve Bank estimates that Australia's risk of recession over this year and next could be as high as 80 per cent.

image.altText: Raging flames in a bushfire setting.

items.synopsis: Months of smoke aerosols profusely pumping into the atmosphere during the 2019–2020 bushfires likely triggered a chain reaction that influenced the onset and intensity of the La Niña events, a US study has found.

title.children: Black Summer bushfires may have helped trigger rare triple-dip La Niña

image.altText: Firefighters at fire with shed in background

title.children: Key 'No' Voice camps merge to strengthen referendum campaign

items.synopsis: The WA budget is being announced, with the state expected to confirm a $4 billion surplus. Follow live as we unpack the details.

title.children: WA budget gives households $400 power bill credit as multi-billion dollar surplus confirmed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Western Australia remains the envy of the nation after recording an eye-watering surplus of $4.2 billion as the rivers of gold continue flowing from the resources industry. So who is reaping the benefits of this budget, and who is being left behind?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Winners and losers of the WA budget

featuredLink.title: Are you a winner or a loser in Mark McGowan's 2023 Budget?

children.content: Western Australia remains the envy of the nation after recording an
eye-watering surplus of $4.2 billion
as the rivers of gold continue flowing from the resources
industry.
So who is reaping the benefits
of this
budget, and who is being left behind?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By WA state political reporter James Carmody: Western Australia's position as the nation's strongest economy remains unchallenged, after Premier and Treasurer Mark McGowan confirmed another massive budget surplus of $3.3 billion for the next financial year. Mr McGowan's headline cost-of-living relief measure was a $400 power bill credit to go to every household in the state, in a repeat of a $400 subsidy given out last year. About 350,000 eligible households could receive an $862 credit on their power bill. You can continue reading this breaking story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: #BREAKING: WA records massive $4.2 billion budget surplus

featuredLink.title: WA budget confirms state's position as Australia's strongest economy, amid GST warning

children.content: By WA state political reporter James Carmody:
Western Australia's position as the nation's strongest economy remains unchallenged, after Premier and Treasurer Mark McGowan confirmed another massive budget surplus of $3.3
billion for the next financial year.
Mr McGowan's headline cost-of-living relief measure was a $400 power bill credit to go to every household in the state, in a repeat of
a $400 subsidy given out last year.
About 350,000 eligible households could
receive an $862 credit on their power bill.
You can continue reading this breaking story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Premier will be addressing parliament at 2:00pm WST. We will be carrying that live on our ABC Perth Facebook page. In the meantime, here are some other key questions that will be useful today, writes to economist Conrad Liveris: What is the unemployment rate in WA? The current unemployment rate in WA is 3.6 per cent. Unemployment means the rate of people currently looking for work. The underemployment rate is 5.7 per cent. Underemployment is the rate of people who are looking for work and want more hours. The WA unemployment rate hasn't been above 4 per cent in more than 18 months. Anything below 5 per cent is considered low unemployment, and a market that favours workers. This matters for the budget because so many projects rely on people working on them. Governments can announce new schools or expansions of hospitals, but if they don't have enough people able to work then they will struggle to operate them. What is the inflation rate? Inflation in Perth is at 5.8 per cent. That's a fair bit lower than the national rate of 7 per cent but still concerning. The Reserve Bank has a target inflation rate of 2-3 per cent, so we are double where they want it and it’s the reason they have spent the past year putting up interest rates. Governments are conscious of inflation because it makes it harder for people to cover the cost of living. The high inflation we have at the moment is being driven by essentials for running our lives — things like food, housing and utilities — which are going up faster than the things we can live without, the discretionary items.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mark McGowan to speak at 2:00pm WST

children.content: The Premier will be addressing parliament at 2:00pm WST. We will be carrying that live on our
ABC Perth Facebook page
In the meantime, here are some other key questions that will be useful today, writes to economist
Conrad Liveris:
What is the unemployment rate in WA?
The current unemployment rate in WA is 3.6 per cent. Unemployment means
the rate of people currently looking for work
The underemployment rate is 5.7 per cent. Underemployment is the rate of people who are looking for work and want more hours.
The WA unemployment rate hasn't been above 4 per cent in more than 18 months. Anything below 5 per cent is considered low unemployment, and a market that favours workers.
This matters for the budget because
so many projects rely on people working on them
Governments can announce new schools or expansions of hospitals, but if they don't have enough people able to work then they will struggle to operate them.
What is the inflation rate?
Inflation in Perth is at 5.8 per cent. That's a fair bit lower than the national rate of 7 per cent but still concerning.
The Reserve Bank has a target inflation rate of 2-3 per cent, so we are double where they want it and it’s the reason they have spent the past year putting up interest rates.
Governments are conscious of inflation because it
makes it harder for people to cover the cost of living

The high inflation we have at the moment is being driven by essentials for running our lives — things like food, housing and utilities — which are going up faster than the things we can live without, the discretionary items.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Previously confidential internal RBA research, released under Freedom of Information laws, predicts up to an 80 per cent chance of a recession in Australia by September 2024. The economic modelling, conducted by a senior analyst in the bank's Economic Analysis Department, defined a recession as unemployment increasing by 0.75 of a percentage point over a 12 month period. Conventional models put the risk of this happening at around 50 per cent. However, the analyst believed those models underestimated the risk. Using a different methodology, they found the risk of a recession was between 65-80 per cent over the next two years. The research was conducted in September 2022, just days before the bank slowed the pace of its interest rate rises from 0.5 of a percentage point per meeting to 0.25 of a percentage point. Read more in my story on the research, which the RBA released under FOI today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA warns of up to 80 per cent recession risk

featuredLink.title: RBA research puts Australian recession risk at up to 80 per cent by 2024

children.content: Previously confidential internal RBA research, released under Freedom of Information laws, predicts up to an 80 per cent chance of a recession in Australia by September 2024.
The economic modelling, conducted by a senior analyst in the bank's Economic Analysis Department, defined a recession as unemployment increasing by 0.75 of a percentage point over a 12 month period.
Conventional models put the risk of this happening at around 50 per cent.
However, the analyst believed those models underestimated the risk.
Using a different methodology, they found the risk of a recession was between 65-80 per cent over the next two years.
The research was conducted in September 2022, just days before the bank slowed the pace of its interest rate rises from 0.5 of a percentage point per meeting to 0.25 of a percentage point.
Read more in my story on the research, which the RBA released under FOI today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 fell 0.05 per cent on Thursday, closing at 7,251. The broader All Ordinaries slipped -0.03 per cent to 7,449. Six of 11 sectors ended higher despite the decline in the overall index, with tech and telecommunications closing with the biggest gains. Utilities and miners were the biggest drags on the ASX. Lithium miner Allkem was the top stock on news the company has secured a merger with a New York-listed company. Gold miner Silverlake Resources was the worst performing stock. The company has revised its offer for St Barbara Limited's Leonora assets in Western Australia to $707million. Investors must not have been impressed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX dragged down by utilities and mining sectors
